title: Clicking any pinned extension that opens a dropdown causes browser to hang since 139.0.1 update
content:
Yesterday (Sat 5/31), I woke up to the 139.0.1 update, along with a new behavior that Firefox will hang (and require a Force Quit) any time I click a pinned extension that opens a drop-down interface (e.g. 1Password, Adblock Plus, Pocket).

I've tried disabling all extensions and bringing single ones back (as well as disabling Pocket via about:config) - the result: any extension that opens a dropdown causes the hang, and any extension that runs without opening a dropdown works just fine, regardless of the combination of extensions that are enabled/disabled at the time.

I tried opening Troubleshoot Mode (although it's of little use since my problem seems rooted in extension behavior) - the first several times I tried, it ALSO caused a hang, but now I'm able to turn it on & off without an issue (though the page rendering is wonky within it - I imagine that's just a Troubleshoot Mode thing?). For whatever it's worth, I think the change that preceded it starting to open without hanging was my disabling this [setting] (though it didn't cause any change in the original behavior, which was my initial goal).

I'm running macOS 14.6.1 if it's of any use. Thanks for any troubleshooting ideas!
creator: elliotcolbert

title: unable to login to reddit
content:
I have just noticed today that I cannot login to Reddit with FireFox. After researching the issue, I can confirm the following:

- Followed all steps in: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/troubleshoot-and-diagnose-firefox-problems - MalwareBytes is not installed - Confirmed latest update of FireFox installed - Adblocker/Ublocker disabled - Deleted caches/cookies - Refreshed Firefox then restarted in troubleshoot mode from: Help > Troubleshoot mode > restart > refresh - Created a new profile and tested - Confirmed FireFox is not limited/restricted from accessing private/public network - Confirmed signing into Reddit from other browsers is successful

Please advise how to fix this as FireFox is my primary browser and I'd rather use it for all of my activities screenshot of the error message attached below

title: Firefox 139.0.1 x64 (Windows 11) is very slow to work with HTTPS
content:
Once I visit any web site that uses HTTPS there is approximately a 90% chance it'll take seconds or even minutes to secure the connection. This never happens on other browsers as they load such pages instantaneously.

I already cleaned my data up and removed the extensions, both suspected and innocent bystanders, to no avail.

As stated in the title, I'm using Firefox 139.0.1 x64 on Windows 11 (24H2, build 26100.4061). This started happening after an automatic Firefox update, I never changed anything in my system configuration.

title: Strange font showing up randomly and occasionally in search results and on webpages
content: Attached is an image of the issue. I've looked around online and found people with similar issues, though not that exact fault. At first I was concerned about viruses but I've run multiple virus scans of my computer and there's no other signs I'd associate with one, so I assume it's another variation on that problem. It happens randomly, no specific triggers I can think of. I use three Firefox profiles, and it's happened on two of them. A ton of search results (the attached is just one example, the top results of reddit had this as well) will have seemingly random words replaced like this. This also occured on a page in my university's website. When I try to copy these, they copy as their original words and not the weird symbols. I'm very confused, basically. It doesn't go away on reload, ctrl+shift+r, or cache clearing, but closing and reopening the tab fixes it.

title: aging and a brain injury
content: how does one, who's brain was hammered into a smudge during a near death episode, handle all this wonderful looking updates/changes that you have made... ? I have loved using Firefox for a long time and the new items and methods entice me to try harder. but even finding how to ask this question was hard to ferret out the passage I should look for. I'm not writing to make people feel sorry for me - it is now a fact of my life that it's not as easy as it once was. well, maybe I could handle some sympathy. but a few hints could be useful. hey! that's it. how do I cajole my own brain's app to assist not run away in fright? I find the Troubleshooting information in share data is something for my grandchildren - not me: especially in the manner it is rushed through. k ps: apologies for my grizzles but I need my brain for puzzles when I'm building trees for friends and relations in ancestry.com

title: disable use of address bar for search
content:
I use duckduckgo page for search in Firefox. Hate my search terms hopping up to the address bar. How to stop this?

A previous search on this question came up with a solution which doesn't work, at least not with latest Firefox version (139.0.1 (64-bit).

I.e., type in searchBar "about:config" 

   Accept warning    Search "browser.urlbar.suggest.searches" and change it to false (Do this Only if you want to disable suggesions)    Search "keyword.enabled" and change it to false    Search "browser.urlbar.suggest.searches" and change it to false

DOESN'T WORK.

title: Secure Connection Failed
content:
Hi I'm having an issue with a website that has always worked in the past with Firefox with no issues. The issue is displaying the following message when I try to view the page: "Secure Connection Failed"

"Error code: MOZILLA_PKIX_ERROR_OCSP_RESPONSE_FOR_CERT_MISSING" This is a personal website that I've had up for years and it works with all browsers except Firefox for some reason now. It was if as a light switch flipped. It worked one night and the next morning it came up with this error. My web hosting provider checked it and said everything was good on their end. The site in question is for a band and has no sales or requirements any kind of personal information for people to view it. The website is www.cherokeehighway.com Can you please advise me? Thank you.

title: New Tabs Now Includes Push Pins on Each Icon on Favorites - Firefox 139.0.1
content:
Just updated to 139.0.1 and got a surprise. My New Tab Favorites Icons now have Push Pins in their upper left corners, leaving less space for the icons, so of course my icons are now smaller than before. Why do the people maintaining the system at Mozilla keep messing with the New Tabs? Last time, they thought they needed to include a large image of the Firefox icon, again shrinking the remaining screen real estate for my icons. That got fixed. Now they decided each favorite icon needs a rather large push pin to indicate that it belongs there. Somebody thought this would be a good idea? Why can't they just leave it alone?

I'm posting two screenshot images of my New Tab screen. You will know which is before and which is after.
creator: Prentice3
